title: Before 1 October 2018, will the UN Security Council pass a resolution imposing an arms embargo on South Sudan?
preds: Just after the nick of time....
Not much point changing to 100 is it, since the cut off will be before?  Oh well, seems the UN can achieve something for once.

UNITED NATIONS (Reuters) - The United Nations Security Council is due to vote on Friday on a U.S.-drafted resolution that would impose an arms embargo on South Sudan, five years after civil war broke out in the country, diplomats said on Thursday.
FILE PHOTO: South Sudan President Salva Kiir attends a South Sudan peace meeting as pa A resolution needs nine votes in favor and no vetoes by Russia, China, Britain, France or the United States. Diplomats said they believed the United States had enough votes for the measure to pass and that it was unlikely to be vetoed.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest-un/u-n-security-council-to-vote-friday-on-proposed-arms-embargo-on-south-sudan-idUSKBN1K22XD
iI’d say still more likely than not but not as sure any longer. https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/05/31/world/africa/ap-un-united-nations-south-sudan.html
Russia and China will not approve.

The UNSC passed resolution 2418(2018) giving South Sudanese warring parties until June 30th to sign a "viable" peace treaty. The resolution requires Secretary-General Gutteres to report back to the council on whether fighting continued or a political agreement was reached during the aforementioned period. In the absence of a political agreement, the UNSC members will "consider" taking one of the following measures (or both): 1) Travel bans and asset freezes targeting 6 high-ranking South Sudanese belligerents 2) An arms embargo, the target and scope of which remains unspecified.  The US-sponsored resolution was said to be watered-down and passed 9-0, with six abstentions. Bolivia, China, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan, and Russia were the abstainers.  In clarifying the rationale for the Russian abstention, Russia's UN ambassador came out strongly against possible sanctions and an arms embargo, calling them "wrong-headed" and doubting their effectiveness in bringing an end to the conflict. He went so far as to attack the US delegation for their "damaging and disrespectful position." China also expressed doubt as to the usefulness of sanctions in ending the conflict, noting that they "would instead further complicate the situation." The Chinese did not mention the possibility of an arms embargo.  So, despite Russia and China's non-objection to including the phrase "will consider...an arms embargo" in the resolution, it's clear from their statements that they are unlikely to acquiesce to a future resolution that attempts to impose a full-blown arms embargo. Add to this the amount of watering-down and wrangling that went into just producing this very lukewarm, non-committal resolution, and an arms embargo seems even less likely to pass. The main factor that could increase this assessment would be the occurrence of a major, media-attention-grabbing escalation of fighting on the ground. https://undocs.org/S/RES/2418(2018)  https://www.un.org/press/en/2018/sc13361.doc.htm https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/06/threatens-arms-embargo-south-sudan-180601054215777.html

Seems like my high forecast was misplaced.... Again, one vote is missing for a resolution on targeted sanctions (not even an arms embargo). And the peace talks just failed days before. "May 28, 2018 (JUBA) - The United Nations Security is short of a vote required to impose sanctions on five senior South Sudanese officials, Gordon Buay, an envoy at its embassy in the United States disclosed. Buay, the chargé d’affairs at South Sudan’s embassy in the U.S., said seven countries made it clear they will not support a U.S. resolution calling for a travel ban and asset freezes of five South Sudan nationals. “In order for the draft resolution to be adopted by the Security Council, the U.S. must get nine votes out of fifteen. However, the U.S. failed to get nine. Washington got only eight,” he told Sudan Tribune Monday." http://sudantribune.com/spip.php?article65513

An embargo has been proposed, US acted unilaterally (and ineffectively), basically no movement since March/April. Looks like another large development is needed to compel attention and move the needle; until then, inertia (AKA base rate) says no embargo.

WoC@ 15% so I'm 0%. China will just veto anyway if they voted on it given the Israel, Syria, Russia, Iran DPRK et al distractions. The Commies are desperate to curry any favour and sell arms to make a buck. Load 'em up on debt in exchange for resources. Simple.

US imposed a unilateral arms embargo back in February, and Nikki Haley has been pushing this issue at the UN Security Council. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-southsudan-arms-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-to-impose-arms-embargo-on-south-sudan-to-end-conflict-sources-idUSKBN1FM0ZE
https://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article65331

1) Although all UNSC member states agreed to the latest resolution threatening an arms embargo, in the past AU member states, China, and Russia have been reluctant to vote yes, instead choosing to abstain. The threat was also part of a much larger resolution that included reauthorization of peace keeping operations and other critical items, so it's not a clear indication of how member states would vote if an actual arms embargo were brought up  2) Even assuming a resolution would pass, the last resolution was passed in March, so its is unlikely to come up again before the council during the specified time period in the absence of a significant attention-grabbing triggering event on the ground 3) South Sudan has entered the rainy season during which major rebel activity tends to decline but communal militia activity, particularly cattle raiding, tends to increase
Failed in 2015.  Failed in 2016.  While DJT is a better negotiator, this is low priority.

It does not appear that there is much motion on this front, as much as the US has publicly declared its intent to push this.  In addition, while there may be fewer abstentions in a future vote, there may also be more motivation from China/Russia to veto such a resolution.

The United States has in the past called for the banning of weapons in South Sudan, and been a vote away from an embargo. As violence continues in the region, It could be suggested that the phenomena of chainganging would push the other members of the UNSC to follow the US's example, and take a more aggressive stance to stabilize the region.

After many years since the start of the civil war in South Sudan, the US imposed an arms embargo on the state in February, signaling that the international community must do more to end the conflict. At that time, the State Dept.'s spokeswoman said the administration would start to resume a push for the UN Security Council to impose a global arms ban against South Sudan. Less than a month ago, the UN Security Council adopted a US-drafted resolution that didn't impose an arms embargo but, “expresses its intention to consider all measures, including an arms embargo, as appropriate, to deprive the parties of the means to continue fighting and to prevent violations” of the December cease-fire agreement. Given recent development, as well as horrific media reports that have gotten attention recently that 40 officials may be individually responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity in South Sudan, I predict a 65% chance of a global arms embargo on South Sudan by October 1st. EU says it will go along. But will an embargo pass the Security Council?
After the veto by Russia on the approved Syrian Cease fire in the name of protecting national sovereignty, I continue to lower this with time.

With new information released by the UN today on human rights atrocities (see for example http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/02/south-sudan-officials-guilty-war-crimes-report-180223152525125.html), the Security Council may be pressured into finally passing a resolution of this nature. This is something the US clearly wants (as other forecasters have already noted). Also, the composition of the UNSC has changed since Dec. 2016 when a previous resolution failed. I would put the probability higher, but Russia and/or China could decide to veto an arms embargo resolution.

US embargo, but it won't get past the Security Council. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-protests/hundreds-protest-against-u-s-arms-embargo-in-south-sudan-journalists-attacked-idUSKBN1FQ22E

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-southsudan-arms-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-to-impose-arms-embargo-on-south-sudan-to-end-conflict-sources-idUSKBN1FM0ZE
The unilateral US move will have no particular effect, except it will allow the other permanent members to pretend to be dead when the issue comes up.

The United States wants to impose an arms embargo, but may face resistance at the U.N. from China, who has invested heavily in South Sudan’s oil fields. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-african-union-summit-southsudan/african-union-joins-growing-chorus-demanding-sanctions-on-south-sudan-war-idUSKBN1FI2IO?il=0

The only way this could happen is if Japan can be swayed to not abstain next time, but I think China or Russia will then veto because of distrust with being locked into their relations with nations at the behest of the US

Coming up a bit, but I don't think anything like this will pass the Council.  My guess, which I am too lazy to confirm, is that the US doesn't sell arms in any large quantity in South Sudan, but Russia or China or both do.  Historically the US has been much less sanctimonious in similar situations if our folks are making lots of money from whatever it is.
UN is obsolete and to fractionalized
Looks like UN will give South Sudan at least until March before taking further action. Thanks to links from @TiltedAxis. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/667210
Good chance but it might be after 10/1/18

http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/south-sudan/ http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/12/14/un-security-council-warns-on-south-sudan-peace-efforts.html, demonstrating commitment to the current United Nations plans for the country. https://townhall.com/news/politics-elections/2017/12/14/un-security-council-warns-on-south-sudan-peace-efforts-n2422798.  The security council voted to extend the current scheme until 15 Mar.  Unless there is an emergency meeting of the Security council on this issue, I do not predict an embargo starting before 16 March 2018. https://www.voanews.com/a/un-security-council-rejects-arms-embargo-south-sudan/3648327.html: reported on 23 Dec 2016.  "The measure received seven votes in favor, while eight countries abstained. The resolution needed nine votes to pass, as well as no vetoes by permanent council members."  Of the five permanent members, US, UK, and France voted for the proviso.  China and Russia must not veto the measure, in order for it to pass.  On the other side, Japan, which has some 350 troops serving in the UN mission in South Sudan, had warned the resolution would have antagonised Kiir's government and put peacekeepers' lives at risk.  I've yet to find comments concerning Russia, China, and Venezuela votes against.  If you do, would you post the source? Traditionally, arms embargoes work best against state agents, such as a nation's army.  Once fighting is being funded at the grass-roots level, the supply lines often include black-market, over-boarder infiltration, and more. Tribal wars are some of the toughest to control, let alone to end.  Ethnic conflicts are at the most difficult end of that spectrum. Having said that, The Security Council warned (source: AP)  Thursday of "costs or consequences" for South Sudan's government and opposition if they undermine upcoming" efforts to generate peace.  I suspect that by 14 Mar 2018, the UNSC will have considered an embargo again.  However, two more nations must vote for it, for it to pass.
UN Security Council can’t agree on anything.

US talking tough again: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-21/u-s-vows-tough-sanctions-if-south-sudan-doesn-t-end-conflict There are 10 months to go on this question, so it could happen. It's not clear to me if Russia or China would veto an arms embargo (as opposed to a blanket embargo).

The United States could not even win over its ally Japan, which last month deployed troops to a U.N. peacekeeping mission in South Sudan. Japan, Russia, China, Angola, Malaysia, Venezuela, Egypt and Senegal all abstained.
“We’re not in favor of using sanctions to exert pressure on developing countries,” China’s Deputy U.N. Ambassador Wu Haitao said. “There needs to be prudent actions with respect to embargoes and designations to avoid complicating the situation even further in South Sudan.”

COMMENT:  The article is from a year ago. Nothing has changed since.

The UN Security Council has failed to impose an arms embargo on South Sudan and couldn’t agree to impose additional individual sanctions on two South Sudanese implicated in serious human rights abuses. These repeated failures on the international stage have contributed to the atmosphere of impunity enjoyed at home by South Sudanese leaders on both sides, and seems to have emboldened their stance.
https://www.alleastafrica.com/2017/10/30/un-security-council-worried-s-sudan-amid-formations-53-new-rebel-groups/ UN as ineffective and useless as always. It is past time another nation did what Nihon did in 1933 and pull out. Time to put this institution out of its misery.
https://www.upi.com/Archives/1933/02/24/Japan-stuns-world-withdraws-from-league/2231840119817/

Africa is going to be in the news more and more in 2018. Passing Security Council can be tough, the devolution of hopes and dreams for North and South Sudan have crashed. It's bloody now and will get worse. China had spent a lot in the area and it is going up in smoke and bodies.

Not impossible. The failure to impose an embargo in December was due to abstentions, not a veto. It's unclear to me if Russia would veto. And would it trade its vote for something else? How much does Russia care? There is a lot of pressure to "do something" about South Sudan. The UN has an arms embargo on parts of Sudan, which it has renewed and refined several times. On the other hand, Sudan (north, south, or unified) has been almost perpetually in a state of war for 60 years, so it tends not to seem pressing to the rest of the world.
Dropping to zero as the fundamentals on the council haven't changed since the last time they failed to impose an embargo.

UN has too many other issues ( e.g. North Korea ) to do something meaningful on South Sudan in the next three weeks. Leaving a 1% chance because Russia was able to land 40 tons of weapons last week and may thus be less interested in vigorously defending the rights of South Sudan to defend itself for a couple of months.
https://africanspress.org/2017/08/31/40-tons-of-south-sudan-weapons-land-at-entebbe/
It seems like other issues take more prominence.

Following @fburdine and also on account of this: https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/jul/04/people-burned-to-death-in-homes-by-south-sudan-government-militias-amnesty-report OTOH, the UN Security Council has had plenty of reasons over the years to impose an embargo, but never has.

Decreasing probability again because neighboring countries who are in contact with the UN have set a Oct 2018 timeline for an election.
https://www.ft.com/content/dc855d9a-501c-11e7-bfb8-997009366969 My guess is that the UN uses the deadline as motivation to put off a vote. Leaving a 10% chance that the Oct 18 is just another artificial deadline and the embargo could be viewed as additive.
While violence continues and famine remains a serious threat to the stability of South Sudan, the imposition of an arms embargo currently seems to be unlikely.
even all this war btween  the tirbes thier  the south sudan still have north sudan as   major anyme  west well not let north sqush the south agien
My gut says the odds are higher but I don't see evidence to corroborate yet.

I am currently hedging low right now, as I feel the current situation is unlikely to lead to the quick passage of an embargo. Indeed, hostilities (and unfortunately atrocities) must ratchet up for a serious move to impose the arms embargo, and I believe we will be forewarned early enough to change our predictions. While it has been pointed out that the current ceasefire is conveniently during the rainy season, it has definitely bought Salva Kiir some time from the skeptical Security Council members (particularly Russia and China). This season should last until October or November, so hostilities will likely remain at a low until then. Low level hostilities will keep S. Sudan low on the radar for SC members other than the U.S., who seem eager to push it. Should a new atrocity perpetrated by SPLA troops occur before October 2018 (which is very much a possibility), I believe that the issue will be reignited and world opinion swayed to the point were enough votes are mustered to pass the embargo.
prior attempts failed, Russia and China say "no" and a ceasefire? I feel like I am missing something.

Big decrease since South Sudan President issued a "unilateral ceasefire."  It will be more difficult to get UN security council to approve an embargo if the government is trying to make peace.
http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article62541
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-security-un-idUSKBN18K2RH
I would expect 1 or 2 abstentions from permanent members. Last such resolution was in 2015. Most others embargoes are frequent but only extensions.

The U.S has too many priorities elsewhere. While this is an important issue, it's not a HOT topic and it seems like if the U.S isn't leading the way on calling for these sanctions, nothing will happen. We'd need a major change in current U.S policies for something to happen.
Don't believe the required number of UN members will be swayed

According to the Dutch minister of Foreign Affairs new UN-sanctions against South-Sudan are not very likely in the near future. He names a few reasons: There is resistance against an embargo in the region, some council-members don't want to discourage attempts from Kiir to improve the situation, others prioritise national sovereignty, and some just don't care about South-Sudan. Link to minutes of the meeting can be found here (in Dutch): https://www.tweedekamer.nl/kamerstukken/verslagen (title: 'Verslag van een algemeen overleg, gehouden op 19 april 2017, over Zuid-Sudan')
Even if this was to be put before the Council it would mostly likely be vetoed

While an embargo would be a very helpful step in dealing with this problem, I just don't see what's changed since December when the arms embargo resolution came up two votes short. The only possibility I see is that in June three of the members who voted against the arms embargo will be replaced and perhaps the US will try and push an embargo again. But that possibility seems remote as I'm not sure if the new members will feel any differently.

I'm starting with 70%. Using Instability as a metric (sadly, S. Sudan isn't on the list: http://www.theglobaleconomy.com/rankings/wb_political_stability/), I come up with a top ten list of Syria, Yemen, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Somalia, Iraq, Libya, DRC, Sudan and CAR. Though it's not in the list, I believe S. Sudan fits among this list and can use it as a rough template. Of those countries, I see all but Pakistan and Afghanistan have embargoes so outside view is 80%~. Due to uncertainty and @chigginson 's analysis, I'm walking it back to 70% EDIT: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Fragile_States_Index. South Sudan is second on this list of fragile states below Somalia and above C.A.R., Sudan, Yemen, and Syria.
I don't see the UN making this a top priority, among other geopolitical concerns that tend to grab more headline space. Hope I'm wrong, however.

The reputation of the UN is closely linked to the success of South Sudan as an independent nation.  South Sudan is the newest UN recognized state and the country is currently recovering from mass genocide.  South Sudan has an official government, but the infrastructure of the country is below third world.  UN Food drops, NGOs, etc are currently keeping many of the South Sudanese people alive.  If the UN Security Council passed a resolution imposing an arms embargo, the warlords and black market arms dealers would thrive and chaos would ensue again.  The only circumstance I predict would cause an arms embargo would be if the UN sanctioned government began committing war crimes with regularity.  Between today and October 1, 2018, I believe South Sudan will avoid a UN arms embargo.
Too busy, and no real attention or national security interests by the permanent members to bother wasting time on it

Based off of the last vote and likely voting patterns we have-
In favor: US, UK, France, Ukraine, Uruguay, Italy, Sweden
Abstain: Russia, China, Bolivia, Egypt, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan
Swing votes: Japan, Senegal I think Japan is possible (60%) to swing, as the removal of their peacekeepers suggests, but Senegal is not (20%). African nations do not often vote to impose such measures on one another, and there is no evidence that Senegal would buck this trend. With all of this in mind, I would start at a 12% chance that both Japan and Senegal change their votes to yes [P(Japan) * P(Senegal)]. This gives the initial rate for 2017. Two other important considerations:  1) Vetoes: It is unlikely, but Russia or China could veto the measure if the US does get the votes. Call it a 10% risk (given that the US get the votes) and lower the overall rate to 11% [12% - (12% x 10%)] 2) The deadline for this question is 1 October 2018, which means that five new members (plus The Netherlands who is taking the second half of Italy's term via a term-splitting agreement) will be elected to the council on 2 June and take their seats on 1 January 2018 (http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/unsc_elections_2017.pdf). Egypt and Senegal will be replaced by Côte d’Ivoire and Equatorial Guinea, Japan by Kuwait, Ukraine by Poland, and Uruguay by Peru. If these countries are presented with a resolution, Kuwait is in a very similar situation as Japan was, likely to be wary about its peacekeepers on the ground and the effect of sanctions on a country they have been historically invested in. At the same time, their positive relationship with the US is probably more valuable, and it's likely Haley can convince them (80%). Neither Côte d’Ivoire or Equatorial Guinea are much more likely to vote yes than Egypt or Senegal, especially given the bilateral partnership Equatorial Guinea just signed with S. Sudan and Ivory Coast's recent experience with a UN mission and sanctions within its own borders. The more likely of the two is probably Ivory Coast. Peru, Netherlands, and Poland can all generally be expected to vote in line with the countries that they are succeeding. I think the key consideration here is going to be the probability that Kuwait and either Ivory Coast or Equatorial Guinea vote yes, defined as P(Kuwait) * [P(Côte d’Ivoire) + P(Equatorial Guinea)], roughly .8 * (.2+.1) = .24 So my forecast is: 
Before the end of 2017 (with current members): 11%
After 2017 (with Kuwait, Netherlands, Poland, Côte d’Ivoire and Equatorial Guinea): 24%
Overall= P(2017 or 2018) = P(2017) + P(2018) = .11+.24 = .35
Too many political issues in conflict to impose mandatory arms embargo

The situation is South Sudan continues to be unstable, with famine at the door, expected to worsen during the coming summer months. International support would be more difficult in a situation of armed conflict, and there should not be much interest to add another  armed crisis to the international political situation. Therefore I believe there will be international interest in an arms embargo. Currently the US are promoting an arms embargo but could not yet get the necessary majority, with eight abstentions in a December vote (http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-4444798/US-pushes-UN-consider-arms-embargo-South-Sudan.html). It appears that resistance was posed by Russia, China, Japan and Egypt, and though I can immagine the Russian and Chinese interest, and possibly those of Egypt, I do not see why Japan should not favor an embargo.  The timeframe to October should be sufficiently large even for a slow moving giant like the UN to come to a resolution.
Overall I thus believe there is good reason but no certainty. A 60% thus would be a good guess.
However, I do would like to be in the top of the scoring for a question at least once! And on a black or white question like this one there is no chance to get there with a well argumented good and realistic percentage but only by a yes or no answer: therefore I put a 100%, against my better knowledge (with the hope to give the masterminds of how to measure forecasting capacities with the brier score does still have a significant weakness when applied to yes or no questions).
The US did push it but the Security Council is still divided. https://www.yahoo.com/news/us-pushes-un-again-consider-arms-embargo-south-174736413.html
With so much political international issues a UN Security vote can always be used as a political leverage piece.

It appears President Kiir is seeking means to make changes. Replacing the military chief so quickly shows resolve to make corrections in a swift manner. External perceptions appear to be this sensitive aspect for the president.

The UN security council is stacked with US allies, so this resolution should pass even though it failed last year. 1.Permanent and Non-Permanent Members The Council is composed of 15 Members:     five permanent members: China, France, Russian Federation, the United Kingdom, and the United States,
    and ten non-permanent members elected for two-year terms by the General Assembly (with end of term date):
        Bolivia (2018)
        Egypt (2017)
        Ethiopia (2018)
        Italy (2018)
        Japan (2017)
        Kazakhstan (2018)
        Senegal (2017)
        Sweden (2018)
        Ukraine (2017)
        Uruguay (2017)
https://www.un.org/en/sc/members/ 2. Nine votes needed to pass. Last vote failed by 7 Votes in Favour, 8 Abstentions.
Voting in favour of the draft resolution were representatives of France, New Zealand, Spain, Ukraine, United Kingdom, United States and Uruguay. 
https://www.un.org/press/en/2016/sc12653.doc.htm

1) 9 votes from the UN Security council are required.
When this was last voted on these seven voted for it: France, New Zealand, Spain, Ukraine, Uruguay, the UK and the US.
Of those France, Ukraine, Uruguay, UK and US are still on the council.  That gives 5 votes. Those that abstained last time: Angola, China, Egypt, Japan, Malaysia, Russia, Senegal and Venezuela.
Of these, China, Russia, Egypt, Japan, and Senegal still are council members. Those that are new council members are Bolivia, Italy, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan, Sweden. http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/un-documents/south-sudan/
https://www.un.org/en/sc/members/ 2) Among the new council members, I assume Italy and Sweden will vote for it since the EU already seems to have an embargo.
That gives 7.  Two more are needed. https://www.sipri.org/databases/embargoes/eu_arms_embargoes/south_sudan 3) For the other new council members: Bolivia, Ethiopia, Kazakhstan
Ethiopia is in a state of emergency.  They probably would not like to have similar imposed on them.
Kazakhstan I believe depends too much on Russian trade to not abstain.
Bolivia I don't think will want to support any resolution that the US drafts. 4) We are left with trying to get votes from previous abstainers.
US tried to get Senegal, Angola and Japan last time.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-security-un-idUSKBN14A1PS Japan has started pulling troops from Sudan.  The troops at risk were one reason they abstained on the last vote.  I think there is high probability they will now vote for it: http://www.humanosphere.org/world-politics/2017/04/japan-begins-pull-troops-south-sudan-peacekeeping-mission/ . One more vote is needed from Angola or Senegal.  I see both as possible to turn to yes - especially since Angola is facing an influx of refugees itself from Congo.  They may have more empathy for countries taking in South Sudan refugees. 5) Nikki Haley thinks it is an important issue:
https://www.yahoo.com/news/us-pushes-un-again-consider-arms-embargo-south-174736413.html I give a 60 percent chance that Haley convinces Angola or Senegal and can muster a vote by Oct.

With the administration distracted by the Russia investigations, purging career civil servants, and whipping Republicans over health care, this is a prime opportunity for Nikki Haley to flex American diplomatic muscle and build her foreign policy credentials for a future WH run. With a desire by the FP establishment to return to America's primacy in the world arena, and an arms embargo requiring relatively little effort by the U.S., I assess this at 65%.

The current problem is abstentions and not permanent-member vetoes.  If neither President Littlefingers nor anyone in his family, his staff or his cabinet is profiting mightily from arms sales to South Sudan, he may well let whatever professional diplomats are left in State work on this.
